data.body:
It's very good as your performance stats show. I thought to say in Meteor we get BSON or it transports behind the scene Binary JSON. (It's actually I think binary EJSON which adds better handling for types like dates.
https://github.com/meteor/js-bson/blob/master/README.md
Maybe this gives the challanged mind some further thoughts on the subject, or not.
I wondered if the synergistic combo is more efficient or if one supersedes the other or which is better or what? Bit of a Blackbox/NDA issue to say or clarify anything more then just that hint, but  your efforts deserve some hopefully useful feedback.
Also noted is the testable wisdom, does packing and unpacking save much if your connection is even faster in the future, as in G5 or whatever you want to call it. Textures for sure, code maybe not so.

Hi @wavesoft 

Here are my results Chrome latest/Win 10/~25mbs download speeds/cache emptied. I also ran the test om a Google Pixel Chromebook and obtained similar results.

![image](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/547626/12879224/e2923462-cde4-11e5-8973-dee15642a4e3.png)

I ran the test with the console open and note that several Three.js errors appeared:

```
compact[vrml]: 73.226ms
three.min.js:344 THREE.JSONLoader: "morphColors" no longer supported. Using them as face colors.
three.min.js:331 Loader.createMaterial: Unsupported colorAmbient Array[3](anonymous function) @ three.min.js:331
three.min.js:344 THREE.JSONLoader: "morphColors" no longer supported. Using them as face colors.
three.min.js:331 Loader.createMaterial: Unsupported colorAmbient Array[3](anonymous function) @ three.min.js:331
jbb_test_timing.html:78 source[animated]: 144.895ms
jbb_test_timing.html:88 compact[animated]: 169.987ms
9three.min.js:381 THREE.MeshPhongMaterial: 'diffuse' is not a property of this material.
jbb_test_timing.html:78 source[heavy]: 602.863ms
jbb_test_timing.html:88 compact[heavy]: 543.567ms
6three.min.js:695 THREE.ImageUtils.loadTexture is being deprecated. Use THREE.TextureLoader() instead.
```

Maybe these affected the testing. I did run the test a number of time.

I think that wahat @MasterJames suggested may be relevant: packing and unpacking may not give much of a speed up when you have a fast connection.

Ah, @theo-armour can you also check if the `.jbb` and `.jbbp` files are served with `Content-Encoding: gzip`? The JBB format is quite sparse and it greatly benefits from GZIP compression. I relied on rawgit doing the gzip compression for me, but they might skip this on fast networks. can you confirm?

@wavesoft 

I will look into these things this evening ( San Francisco time ) - but please not that I am one of the Thjree.js 'dummies' and not a techie - so I may not understand what this all means. ;-)

@theo-armour open the Developer Tools, go to `Network` tab, and having the developer tools open, click on _Start Tests_. You will see all the resources being downloaded... click on the `vrml.jbb`, select the `Headers` tab on the right, and look for a `Content-Encoding: gzip` header on the Response Headers. Check if this is missing in your case.

You can also click on `Timing` tab to see were your browser spends more time while downloading.

for vrml.jbb

```
HTTP/1.1 200 OK
Date: Mon, 08 Feb 2016 23:47:57 GMT
Content-Type: application/octet-stream
Transfer-Encoding: chunked
Connection: keep-alive
X-Content-Type-Options: nosniff
X-Robots-Tag: none
Access-Control-Allow-Origin: *
Cache-Control: max-age=315569000
ETag: W/"7f259ba2c77bf142181e8815455ac53def20fef9"
Vary: Accept-Encoding
RawGit-Cache-Status: HIT
Server: NetDNA-cache/2.2
X-Cache: HIT
Content-Encoding: gzip
```

![image](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/547626/12903401/3dad54fc-ce7c-11e5-9ccc-88e6de753f48.png)

Hello guys! I worked a bit further on the jbb format, making sure that it's parsing time is always faster than the loader that I use. Even though I still see some corner cases, I observe an average loading time improvement of about **30%**.

You can run the [benchmarks of the latest version here](https://cdn.rawgit.com/wavesoft/jbb-tests/7d71eb26378860d4059097f3ee6d41fb0940299b/jbb_test_timing.html), and please let me know if you still see bad results. 

I also wrote a quick guide for [how `.jbb` can be used with three.js](https://github.com/wavesoft/jbb/blob/master/doc/Tutorial%201%20-%20THREEjs/Using%20with%20THREEjs.md). Note that I tested it with three.js r73.

If I am correct there have been some API changes since r73 and I need to update the [jbb-profile-three](https://github.com/wavesoft/jbb-profile-three) accordingly in order to make it compatible with the latest release.

This looks great, nice work! 🎉 

I'm going to close the issue unless there are any specific ways three.js should accommodate this use case better, but for discussion/benchmarks/updates feel free to start a new thread in the [three.js forums](https://discourse.threejs.org/) as well.
